last_200_tokens: found that ERCC6 (ENSG00000225830) is the most likely causal gene. Here's my reasoning: 1. The patient has a complex phenotype pattern involving multiple systems: - Eye abnormalities: Anophthalmia (HP:0000528), Optic atrophy (HP:0000648) - Neurological/motor dysfunction: Parkinsonism (HP:0001300), Upper motor neuron dysfunction (HP:0002493), Gait disturbance (HP:0001288), Hypertonia (HP:0001276), Rigidity (HP:0002063), Hyperreflexia (HP:0001347), Abnormal pyramidal sign (HP:0007256), Abnormal lower-limb motor evoked potentials (HP:0012898) - Speech/behavioral changes: Irritability (HP:0000737), Impulsivity (HP:0100710), Abnormal speech pattern (HP:0002167), Abnormal diminished volition (HP:0000745) 2. From the OMIM data, I found that ERCC6 is associated with "Cerebrooculofacioskeletal syndrome 1" which literally means "brain-eye-facial-skeletal" syndrome. 3. This syndrome would explain: - "Cerebro" - brain/neurological involvement (matches Parkinsonism, upper motor neuron dysfunction, etc.) - "Oculo" - eye involvement (matches anophthalmia, optic atrophy) - "Facio" - facial involvement - "Skeletal" - bone/structural involvement 4. Other candidate genes only explain single aspects of the phenotype: - PANK2: Neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation (neurological only) - SEMA4A: Retinitis pigmentosa, Cone-rod dystrophy (eye only) - SLC33A1: Spastic paraplegia (motor only) - ZNF711: Intellectual developmental disorder (developmental only) 5. ERCC6 is the only gene that provides comprehensive explanation for both eye and neurological/motor phenotype clusters. The answer is {'causal_gene': ['ENSG00000225830']}. </think> <solution> {'causal_gene': ['ENSG00000225830']} </solution>
